title: All Caps Sans
content:
It seems an obvious one but for the life of me I can remember!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090924021503im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Picture_1_6115.png)
author: smongey

comments.content: [Johnston Underground Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20090924021503/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/p22/underground/) is similar, but I dont think it’s an exact match.

Another similar font is Device’s English Grotesque:  
 [http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/device\_fonts/english\_grotesque/](http://web.archive.org/web/20090924021503/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/device_fonts/english_grotesque/ "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/device\_fonts/english\_grotesque/")
The S is quite different from the English Grotesque’s S.

I think P22’s Underground Pro might be doing the trick!

[http://www.p22.com/products/typecaster.html#Underground%20Full%20Set](http://web.archive.org/web/20090924021503/http:/www.p22.com/products/typecaster.html#Underground%20Full%20Set "http://www.p22.com/products/typecaster.html#Underground%20Full%20Set")

“The S is quite different from the English Grotesque’s S.”

You missed the word “similar” in my post. The C in English Grotesque is also very different.  
I thought that smongery may be looking for something with the same character.
Underground from P22 is VERY similar to Johnston. The distinct diamond dot on the ’i’ in the Johnston family is the same in Underground, as is the g and y similar...
